style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ePunsaen Boonyakarn, Shawn Chew, Logeswaran Nadarajan, Mathew Potaczek, Jakub Jozwiak, Alex Marvi\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eFollowing the discovery of \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/threat-intelligence/esxi-hypervisors-malware-persistence/\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003emalware residing within ESXi hypervisors\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e in September 2022, Mandiant began investigating numerous intrusions conducted by UNC3886, a suspected China-nexus cyber espionage actor that has targeted prominent strategic organizations on a global scale. In January 2023, Mandiant provided \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/threat-intelligence/chinese-actors-exploit-fortios-flaw/\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003edetailed analysis of the exploitation of a now-patched vulnerability in FortiOS\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e employed by a threat actor suspected to be UNC3886. In March 2023, we provided details surrounding a custom \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/threat-intelligence/fortinet-malware-ecosystem/\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003emalware ecosystem utilized on affected Fortinet devices\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. Furthermore, the investigation uncovered the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/threat-intelligence/chinese-actors-exploit-fortios-flaw/\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ecompromise of VMware technologies\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e, which facilitated access to guest virtual machines.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eInvestigations into more recent operations in 2023 following fixes from the vendors involved in the investigation have corroborated Mandiant's initial observations that the actor operates in a sophisticated, cautious, and evasive nature. Mandiant has observed that UNC3886 employed several layers of organized persistence for redundancy to maintain access to compromised environments over time. Persistence mechanisms encompassed network devices, hypervisors, and virtual machines, ensuring alternative channels remain available even if the primary layer is detected and eliminated.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThis blog post discusses UNC3886's intrusion path and subsequent actions that were performed in the environments after compromising the guest virtual machines to achieve access to the critical systems, including:\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe use of publicly available rootkits for long-term persistence\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eDeployment of malware that leveraged trusted third-party services for command and control (C2 or C\u0026amp;C)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eSubverting access and collecting credentials with Secure Shell (SSH) backdoors\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eExtracting credentials from TACACS+ authentication using custom malware \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant has published \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/threat-intelligence/esxi-hypervisors-detection-hardening/\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003edetection and hardening guidelines for ESXi hypervisors\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e and \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/threat-intelligence/vmware-detection-containment-hardening/\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eattack techniques employed by UNC3886\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. For Google SecOps Enterpri\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ese+ customers, rules hav\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ee been released to your \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/chronicle/docs/preview/curated-detections/windows-threats-category\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eEmerging Threats\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e rule pack, and indicators of compromise (IOCs) listed in this blog post are available for prioritization with \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/chronicle/docs/detection\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eApplied Threat Intelligence\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. Mandiant recommends that organizations follow the security recommendations within the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://core.vmware.com/vsphere-esxi-mandiant-malware-persistence\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eVMware\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e and \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.fortiguard.com/psirt/FG-IR-22-369\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003eFortinet\u003c/a\u003e advisories\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e and the security recommendations provided in this blog post.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eZero-Day Exploitation\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eIn January 2024, Mandiant published a blog post detailing \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/threat-intelligence/chinese-vmware-exploitation-since-2021/\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eUNC3886's activities exploiting CVE-2023-34048\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e (VMware vCenter) since late 2021. The exploitation enables unauthenticated remote command execution on vulnerable vCenter servers. Mandiant observed deployment of attacker backdoors minutes after crashing of the vulnerable VMware service.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eCVE-2023-34048 was not the only zero-day vulnerability exploited by UNC3886 during these intrusions. The threat actor exploited three other zero-day vulnerabilities, which have since been patched, to gain access when obtaining and abusing credentials of existing accounts was infeasible. Figure 1 describes the UNC3886 attack path involving the following zero-day exploitations:\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eCVE-2022-41328 in FortiOS was exploited to download and execute backdoors on FortiGate devices.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eCVE-2022-22948 in VMware vCenter was exploited to obtain encrypted credentials in the vCenter's postgresDB for further access.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eCVE-2023-20867\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e in VMware Tools was exploited to execute unauthenticated Guest Operations from ESXi host to guest virtual machines.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"]]],[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[[[null,"\u003cp\u003eFigure 1: UNC3886 attack path diagram\u003c/p\u003e"],["https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig1.max-2200x2200.jpg","https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig1.max-1100x1100.jpg 1060w, https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig1.max-2200x2200.jpg 2120w"," 1060px,  2120px","https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig1.max-2200x2200.jpg"],null,3]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant observed the threat actor exploit CVE-2022-42475 in FortiOS's Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) virtual private network (VPN) to obtain access in January 2023 after details of the vulnerability had been made public by Fortinet as part of their \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.fortiguard.com/psirt_policy\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003evulnerability disclosure processes\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. CVE-2022-42475 allows a remote unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code or commands via specifically crafted requests.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eUse of Publicly Available Rootkits for Long-Term Persistence\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eAfter exploiting zero-day vulnerabilities to gain access to vCenter servers and subsequently managed ESXi servers, the actor obtained total control of guest virtual machines that shared the same ESXi server as the vCenter server. Mandiant observed the actor use two publicly available rootkits, REPTILE and MEDUSA, on the guest virtual machines to maintain access and evade detection.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eREPTILE\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eREPTILE is an open-source Linux rootkit, implemented as a loadable kernel module (LKM), that provides backdoor access to a system. The rootkit and backdoor functionalities are implemented as a separate component identified by Mandiant as follows:\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eREPTILE.CMD is a user-mode component responsible for communicating with the kernel-mode component to perform actions including hiding files, processes, and network connections.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eREPTILE.SHELL is a reverse shell backdoor running in user-mode. The component could be configured to listen for a specialized packet in TCP, UDP, or ICMP for activation.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eREPTILE kernel-level component is an LKM responsible for hooking kernel functions and modifying functions data as tasked by REPTILE.CMD to achieve rootkit functionality.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eREPTILE LKM launcher is responsible for decrypting the actual kernel module code from the file and loading into the memory.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eREPTILE appeared to be the rootkit of choice by UNC3886 as it was observed being deployed immediately after gaining access to compromised endpoints. REPTILE offers both the common backdoor functionality, such as command execution and file transfer capabilities, as well as stealth functionality that enables the threat actor to evasively access and control the infected endpoints via port knocking.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant observed that UNC3886 introduced several changes into the REPTILE code base and its auxiliary components. Some changes are based on the REPTILE code base before version 2.1, which was introduced on March 1, 2020, potentially indicating the actor has been developing and/or operating this rootkit for some time. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eOne such change was identified within the UNC3886 REPTILE LKM launcher. In REPTILE version 2.0, the original developer of REPTILE altered how the kernel-level component is loaded, switching from using \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003einsmod\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e to a \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/f0rb1dd3n/Reptile/blob/965dc73bef36877574a43523fe1b7ec55c52cd9f/loader.c\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ecustom launcher\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. The launcher Mandiant observed UNC3886 use throughout their operations, based on the custom launcher, was updated with a new function to daemonize a process. This function is identical to the publicly available \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/NorthWardTop/posix/blob/master/process/create_daemon.c\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ecreate_daemon.c\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eUNC3886 automated the deployment of REPTILE components with shell scripts. These scripts contained similar code to \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/f0rb1dd3n/Reptile/blob/965dc73bef36877574a43523fe1b7ec55c52cd9f/setup.sh\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ethe installation script\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e responsible for building REPTILE components and configuring a persistence mechanism for the REPTILE kernel-level component. The following additions were observed in the deployment shell script, which resulted in the creation of different forensic artifacts from the original REPTILE:\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe threat actor replaced every instance of \"reptile\" with a unique keyword, which resulted in different filenames for rootkit component files.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cdiv align\u003d\"left\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv The analysis of the REPTILE samples revealed that the REPTILE.CMD was developed to hide file contents enclosed with a string \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e#\u0026lt;/Centos_Selinux_Config_And_Module\u0026gt;\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e when the component is executed with a \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003efile-tampering\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e parameter.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant identified a customized sample of REPTILE listeners with Transport Layer Security (TLS) support. The sample is able to receive communications using TLS over raw Transmission Control Protocol (TCP). Mandiant observed the threat actor deployed the customized version of REPTILE along with the victim's legitimate TLS certificate and private key obtained from the compromised FortiGate devices.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eWhile UNC3886 was observed deploying new rootkits and backdoors with more functionalities, REPTILE appeared to be the first option to establish a foothold and possibly the last resort for maintaining access due to its small footprints.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMEDUSA and SEAELF\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMEDUSA is \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/ldpreload/Medusa\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ean open-source rootkit implementing dynamic linker hijacking via LD_PRELOAD\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. Unlike REPTILE, which only provides an interactive access with rootkit functionalities, MEDUSA exhibits capabilities of logging user credentials from the successful authentications, either locally or remotely, and command executions. These capabilities are advantageous to UNC3886 as their modus operandi to move laterally using valid credentials.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant assessed the use of MEDUSA to be experimental alternatives of REPTILE and SSH keyloggers. The adoption of REPTILE was usually observed after the threat actor successfully gained access to compromised endpoints where it was used to deploy other malware, keyloggers, and utilities. MEDUSA, however, has been deployed subsequently on the same compromised endpoints in more recent activities.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eDeployment of MEDUSA was accomplished by the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/ldpreload/Medusa/blob/main/src/rkload.c\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMEDUSA installer component\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e, identified by Mandiant as SEAELF. Mandiant identified two versions of MEDUSA deployed in the compromised endpoints, both using \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0xAA\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e as the XOR encryption key to encrypt configuration strings. style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant observed the threat actor deploying and executing tools via MEDUSA to capture SSH valid credentials from the compromised endpoints. Upon starting, MEDUSA was configured to execute commands and executables listed under \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/usr/lib/locate/.boot.sh\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e as follows:\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003e/usr/sbin/libvird\r\n/usr/bin/NetworkManage\r\nchcon -t sshd_tmp_t /var/run/cron.data\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe executables and the command constitute a component of the threat actor's attempt to hijack SSH connections with the objective of acquiring SSH credentials. Analysis of the executables and their attempts is discussed later in this report.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMalware Leveraging Trusted Third Parties as C2 Channel\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe threat actor was observed deploying malware, including MOPSLED and RIFLESPINE, that leverages trusted third parties like GitHub and Google Drive as C2 channels while relying on the rootkits for persistence.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMOPSLED\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMOPSLED is a shellcode-based modular backdoor that has the capability to communicate over HTTP or a custom binary protocol over TCP to its C2 server. The core functionality of MOPSLED involves expanding its capabilities by retrieving plugins from the C2 server. MOPSLED also uses a custom ChaCha20 encryption algorithm to decrypt embedded and external configuration files.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant observed sharing of MOPSLED between other Chinese cyber espionage groups including APT41. Mandiant considered MOPSLED to be an evolution of CROSSWALK, which can act as a network proxy.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant observed UNC3886 deploy the Linux variant, identified as MOPSLED.LINUX, on vCenter servers and a small number of the compromised endpoints where REPTILE already existed. MOPSLED.LINUX appeared to be used only as an initial malware deployed after gaining successful access since the malware does not have rootkit-like capabilities that could evade detection.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMOPSLED.LINUX was developed to communicate with a dead-drop URL to retrieve an actual C2 address. The sample associated with UNC3886 was observed sending HTTP GET requests to \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ehttps://cyberponke.github[.]io/*\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. The response was decrypted using the ChaCha20 cipher to obtain the actual C2 IP address. Further communications are implemented as a custom binary protocol similar to HTTP/S.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eRIFLESPINE\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eRIFLESPINE is a cross-platform backdoor that leverages Google Drive to transfer files and execute commands. It adopts the CryptoPP library to implement the AES algorithm to encrypt and decrypt the data transmitted between an affected machine and the threat actor.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eTo instruct RIFLESPINE, the threat actor creates an encrypted file on Google Drive with instructions for RIFLESPINE that is then executed by the malware on the target endpoint. The target endpoint's MAC address must appear in the filename when it is created. The file is downloaded, RIFLESPINE downloads and decrypts the file, and executes the instructions. The executions' outputs will be encrypted, stored in a temporary file, and then uploaded to Google Drive once more. The following instructions are available for execution:\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eDownload file with \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eget\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e command.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eUpload file with \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eput\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e command.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eSet next call out time in milliseconds with \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003esettime.\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eExecution arbitrary commands with \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/bin/sh.\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eUNC3886 deployed RIFLESPINE with \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/prasmussen/gdrive\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ean open-source Google Drive CLI client\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. A systemd service file was created and used to execute the malware as the malware does not contain a persistence mechanism. Upon first installation, the malware collects system information and starts communicating with Google Drive service with the following steps:\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eExecute \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003egdrive\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e to obtain the file pertinent to the target endpoint with the following command:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003egdrive --refresh-token \u0026lt;token\u0026gt; list | grep \u0026quot;2@\u0026lt;mac_address\u0026gt;\u0026quot;\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan command:\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003egdrive --refresh-token \u0026lt;token\u0026gt; download --path \u0026quot;/tmp\u0026quot; -f\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e using CryptoPP AES-CBC with key \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003elibcrypt.so.2\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e and IV \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003elibev.so.5.\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eAfter executing the instructions, write output to \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode decryption.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan upload --name \u0026quot;/tmp\r\n/update\u0026lt;random_number\u0026gt;.tmp.en\u0026quot;\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eDelay and repeat the previous steps.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eSimilar to MOPSLED.LINUX, RIFLESPINE was observed only in a small number of the compromised virtual machines. It is reasonable to assume that the threat actor abandoned the idea of using MOPSLED.LINUX and RIFLESPINE, which do not have rootkit functionality, as backdoors because predictable communications to GitHub and Google Drive services from virtual machine servers, rather than workstations, could raise suspicions.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eSubverting Accesses With Backdoored Applications\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant observed UNC3886 relying heavily on collecting and utilizing valid credentials for lateral movement between guest virtual machines running on the compromised VMware ESXi. The following section describes different techniques used by the threat actor to collect and abuse valid credentials.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eBackdoored SSH Executables\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eAfter gaining access to the guest virtual machines, either through the collection of \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003evpxuser\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e credentials or by exploiting CVE-2023-20867 in conjunction with VMware Guest Operations abuse to facilitate malicious file transfer and execution, UNC3886 was observed deploying backdoored SSH clients and daemons. The purpose of these malicious components was the interception and collection of credentials within an XOR-encrypted text file.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eAnalysis of the compromised SSH client located at \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/usr/bin/ssh\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e exposed modifications by the threat actor to the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003euserauth_passwd()\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e function, which governs password-based authentication. These modifications (detailed in Figure 2) introduce instructions designed to harvest SSH credentials from outgoing connections. The credentials are then XORed with \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0xef\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e before storage in the file \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/var/log/ldapd\u0026lt;unique_keyword\u0026gt;.2.gz\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[[[null,"\u003cp\u003eFigure 2: Backdoored userauth_passwd()function\u003c/p\u003e"],["https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig2.max-1100x1100.png","https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig2.max-1100x1100.png 1058w, https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig2.max-1100x1100.png 1058w"," 1058px,  1058px","https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig2.max-1100x1100.png"],null,3]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eTo facilitate the targeted collection of incoming SSH credentials, threat actors introduced modifications to the SSH daemon executable located at \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/usr/sbin/sshd\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. which is an injector based on a publicly available \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/kubo/injector\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ekubo/injector\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e project embedded with a payload. \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003elibvird\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e creates a library file identified as injects the library to \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003esshd\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e by default if both the target program and the library file are not provided.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant recovered and conducted analysis of the file with the same hash as the payload embedded in \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003elibvird\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. The analysis observed that the payload intercepts \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003echeckfd()\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e of \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003esshd\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e when executed and verifies if the received data contains \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eSSH-2.0-OpenSSH_6pf\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. The payload redirects the stream to the Unix socket \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/var/run/cron.data\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant identified \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/usr/bin/NetworkManage\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e as a SSH server based on a publicly available SSH server \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/wzshiming/sshd\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ewzshiming/sshd\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. The SSH server creates, monitors, and picks up the connection redirected to the Unix socket \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/var/run/cron.data\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eLastly, the final command inside \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/usr/lib/locate/.boot.sh\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e was used to apply the SELinux security context of the Unix socket file \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/var/run/cron.dat\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e to be the predefined \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003esshd_tmp_t\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e context, which is the security context tailored to temporary files used by the SSH daemon. This to ensure that the Unix socket used by the injector and the custom SSH server is accessible and writable when SELinux is enabled.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe threat actor was observed deploying another injector identified as \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003esentry\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e and the custom SSH server identified as \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003esshdng-venter-7.0\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e on another endpoint. Analysis of the two executables identified the same injection and redirection operations as observed with \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003elibvird\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e and \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eNetworkManage\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eToward the Intrusion Goals\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe Remnants of Internal Recon and Lateral Movement\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe objectives of the threat actor were initially unclear due to limited visibility and the extensive use of rootkits, tools, and scripts to eliminate forensic artifacts. When considering goal achievement, it is trivial to assume that a cyber espionage threat actor would focus on specific information. Yet pinpointing the exact type of information becomes challenging as it is situational. After a comprehensive analysis of the unallocated space of the compromised endpoints acting as a jump server, Mandiant identified some evidence that indicated what the threat actor's ultimate intentions may have been.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant successfully recovered scan logs generated by NMAP. The scan logs were created using the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e-oG\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e parameter, which resulted in the recording of detailed scan information, including the NMAP executable, the scan initiation timestamp, the options, and the scan result. The sample log is presented as follows. Note that information related to victim organizations is redacted.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003e# Nmap 6.49BETA1 scan initiated [redacted] as: ./sc -sS -Pn -n \r\n--open --host-timeout 30 -T4 -v -oG result.txt -p 902,2012,4786,443 \r\nA.B.C.D/24\r\n# Ports scanned: TCP(4;443,902,2012,4786) UDP(0;) SCTP(0;) PROTOCOLS(0;)\r\nHost: A.B.C.1 ()\tPorts: 443/open/tcp//https///, \r\n4786/open/tcp//smart-install///\r\n\tIgnored State: filtered (2)\r\nHost: A.B.C.1 ()\tStatus: Up\r\nHost: A.B.C.1 ()\tStatus: Timeout\r\nHost: A.B.C.2 ()\tStatus: Up\r\nHost: A.B.C.2 ()\tPorts: 4786/open/tcp//smart-install///\r\n\tIgnored State: filtered (3)\r\nHost: A.B.C.3 ()\tStatus: Up\r\nHost: A.B.C.3 ()\tPorts: 443/open/tcp//https///\r\n\tIgnored State: filtered (3)\r\nHost: A.B.C.4 ()\tStatus: Up\r\nHost: A.B.C.4 ()\tStatus: Ports: 902/open/tcp//ideafarm-door///\r\n\tIgnored State: filtered (3)\r\nHost: A.B.C.5 ()\tStatus: Up\r\nHost: A.B.C.5 ()\tStatus: Timeout\r\nHost: A.B.C.6 ()\tStatus: Up\r\nHost: A.B.C.6 ()\tPorts: 4786/open/tcp//smart-install///\r\n\tIgnored State: filtered (3)\r\n.......\r\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe following observations were made from the sample scan log:\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eNMAP executable\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e: The threat actor brought their own NMAP executable for scanning. The executable \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003esc\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e was also located on the unallocated space and identified as a stand-alone version of the NMAP.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eScanning parameters\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e: TCP SYN scan was initiated in the aggressive mode without DNS resolution and host discovery, targeting TCP/443, TCP/902, TCP/2012, and TCP/4786 of \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e10.A.B.C/24\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. The result was recorded to \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eresult.txt\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e with a record of only open or possibly open ports.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eScanning results\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e: The result indicates alive hosts with the open ports.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eWith the assumption that the services running on the alive hosts configured with the default port number, the alive hosts identified with TCP/4786 were possibly Cisco network appliances as the port is commonly assigned for Cisco Smart Install (SMI) service. TCP/902 indicates VMware technologies. By aggregating data from other scan logs and validating with the victim, it was established that the targeted networks belonged to foreign networks under the management of the victim organization. This marked the point at which a supply chain attack scenario became conceivable.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe existence of NMAP scan logs suggests that there is connectivity from the jump server to the foreign networks, although accessibility requires legitimate credentials. The final clue aligned with this assumption as the ongoing investigation uncovered malicious activities on a TACACS+ server accessible from the jump server.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eTACACS is a network protocol used in computer networking for providing centralized authentication, authorization, and accounting (AAA) service. TACACS+ represents an enhanced and more robust version of the original TACACS protocol. Network appliances employ TACACS+ for security and access control, ensuring that authenticated users are authorized to execute actions that are monitored for auditing purposes.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eAn unauthorized access to a system functioning as an authentication server like a TACACS+ server is an absolute security nightmare. The threat actor could access or manipulate user credentials and authorization policies stored within its database. Accountability of TACACS+ would also be affected as the threat actor could tamper with the accounting logs stored on the TACACS+ server, covering their tracks and concealing malicious activities.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe following sections describe actions performed by the threat actor to extend their access to the target network appliances.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eCapturing TACACS+ Credentials with LOOKOVER\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe threat actor's first attempt to extend their access to the network appliances by targeting the TACACS server was the use of LOOKOVER. LOOKOVER is a sniffer written in C that processes TACACS+ authentication packets, performs decryption, and writes its contents to a specified file path. LOOKOVER uses the publicly available libpcap library to sniff TCP packets.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe threat actor deployed LOOKOVER on the TACACS+ server at \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/usr/sbin/au\u0026lt;unique_keyword\u0026gt;ditd\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. The sample required the following environment variables to be configured:\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eTKEY\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e - TACACS+ pre-shared key; contains default key \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e7ujm^YHN\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e (required)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eFILTER\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e - libpcap filter string (required)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eDEVICE\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e - libpcap capture device (optional)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eSNFILENAME\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e - processed data output path, optional with default set to \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/var/lib/libsyslog.so\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. All data written to this file is XORed with the single byte \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0xEF\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eAnalysis of the LOOKOVER sample indicates that the samples process TCP packets whose first two bytes of data are \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0xC0\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e and \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0x01\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e and verify if the next byte is \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0x01\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e or \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0x03\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. The pattern aligns with TACACS+ packet header as described in \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8907#name-the-tacacs-packet-header\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eRFC 8907\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e as follows:\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0xC0\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e indicates the major (\u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0xC\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e) and the minor (\u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0x0\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e) TACACS+ version number.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0x01\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e indicates that the packet type is \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eTAC_PLUS_AUTHEN.\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe next byte indicates the sequence number of the current packet; LOOKOVER targets if the sequence number is \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0x01\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e or \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0x03\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e, which are commonly packets sent from the client to the TACACS+ server.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe sample verifies if the flag bit is \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0x0\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e, which indicates that the payload is encrypted. If the flag bit is \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0x0\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e, the sample then performs TACACS+ decryption by incorporating the first 12 bytes of TCP along with \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eTKEY\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e into an MD5 hash and uses the hash to XOR-decode the remainder of the TCP data. The decoded data along with the packet source IP address and an integer from the first 12 bytes are written to \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eSNFILENAME\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eIf the next byte is nonzero, which could indicate a plain text payload, the entire data segment of the TCP packet is written to \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eFILENAME\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[[[null,"\u003cp\u003eFigure 5: LOOKOVER's function responsible for handling TACACS+ packets\u003c/p\u003e"],["https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig5.max-1000x1000.png",null,null,"https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig5.max-1000x1000.png"],null,3]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eDuring the analysis of the compromised TACACS+ server, Mandiant identified the presence of \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/usr/sbin/au\u0026lt;unique_keyword\u0026gt;ditd\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e core dump file. Analysis of the core dump file revealed that the threat actor configured the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eFILTER\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e environment variable as \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eport 49\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e with \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/var/log/tac_cisco_\u0026lt;unique_keyword\u0026gt;_log\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e as \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eSNFILENAME\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. TCP/49 is used by TACACS+ Login Host protocol to handle an authentication request from devices. The process crashed when attempting to encrypt extracted credentials before writing to disks, and this could influence the threat actor to employ another approach to target TACACS+.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eBackdoored TACACS+ Binary\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eOn the same TACACS+ server identified with LOOKOVER, Mandiant observed the threat actor replaced the legitimate \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/usr/bin/tac_plus\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e, which is the TACACS+ daemon for Linux, with a malicious version containing credential logging functionality.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe malicious version of \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/usr/bin/tac_plus\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e was modified with a new function responsible for logging TACACS+ credentials to \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e/var/log/tacu\u0026lt;unique_keyword\u0026gt;cs.log\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e. The function was inserted in the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003everify()\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e after the password was validated and in the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003epasswd_file_verify()\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e, which is responsible for confirming a credential after the password is confirmed to be correct. The captured credential record is XOR-ed with \u003c/span\u003e\u003ccode style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e0xEF\u003c/code\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e before appending to the credential log file.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[[[null,"\u003cp\u003eFigure 6: Malicious function within tac_plus for capturing credentials\u003c/p\u003e"],["https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig6.max-600x600.png",null,null,"https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig6.max-600x600.png"],null,3]]],[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[[[null,"\u003cp\u003eFigure 7: Backdoored authentication function of tac_plus\u003c/p\u003e"],["https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig7.max-700x700.png",null,null,"https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/unc3886-cloaked-covert-fig7.max-700x700.png"],null,3]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003ch2\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eThe Family of VMCI Backdoors\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eMandiant discovered a new variant of backdoors leveraging the Virtual Machine Communication Interface (VMCI) as a communication protocol. The VMCI backdoors could facilitate either guest-to-guest or host-to-guest communications to achieve command execution. See \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/threat-intelligence/vmware-esxi-zero-day-bypass/\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-decoration:underline;vertical-align:baseline\"\u003ethe overview of the attacker's use of ESXi Hypervisor VMCI communications\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e for more information.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eVIRTUALSHINE\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e is a simple VMware VMCI sockets-based backdoor that provides access to a bash shell. VIRTUALSHINE connects to a specified target, which streams the bash pty.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eVIRTUALPIE\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e is a backdoor written in Python that spawns a demonized IPv6 listener on a hard-coded TCP port. It supports file transfer, arbitrary command execution, and reverse shell capabilities. It communicates using a custom protocol and the data is encrypted using RC4.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eVIRTUALSPHERE\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e is the controller part of a simple VMCI-based backdoor. The malware transmits the second command-line argument over the VMCI socket to the server running inside the target VM.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eWe plan to release technical details of the VMCI backdoors in a future blog post.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eCampaign 23-022 and Indicators of Compromise\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eSince March 2023, we have tracked UNC3886 activity leveraging zero-day exploits for Fortinet and VMware technologies as part of \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eCampaign 23-022\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003e in \u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/security/products/mandiant-threat-intelligence\"\u003eMandiant Advantage\u003c/a\u003e for our customers. The majority of organizations that Mandiant has responded to or identified as targets through our own analysis have been located in the North America, Southeast Asia, or Oceania regions. However, we have also identified evidence of additional victims located in Europe, Africa, and other parts of Asia. Industries that Mandiant has observed being targeted are those typically observed in espionage operations, namely governments, telecommunications, technology, aerospace and defense, and energy and utility sectors. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline\"\u003eTo assist the wider community in hunting and identifying activity outlined in this blog post, we have included a subset of these indicators of compromise (IOCs) in this post, and in a \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.virustotal.com/gui/collection/7348124563bbbc386fcda8a66c43de6d1a3dcfd370edff22e3131afe7e3bc9dc\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cspan Bonadan is a malicious version of OpenSSH which acts as a custom backdoor. Bonadan has been active since at least 2018 and combines a new cryptocurrency-mining module with the same credential-stealing module used by the Onderon family of backdoors.[1]
Bonadan can create bind and reverse shells on the infected system.[1]
Bonadan has maliciously altered the OpenSSH binary on targeted systems to create a backdoor.[1]
Bonadan can XOR-encrypt C2 communications.[1]
Bonadan can download additional modules from the C2 server.[1]
Bonadan can use the ps command to discover other cryptocurrency miners active on the system.[1]
Bonadan can download an additional module which has a cryptocurrency mining extension.[1]
Bonadan has discovered the OS version, CPU model, and RAM size of the system it has been installed on.[1]
Bonadan can find the external IP address of the infected host.[1]
Bonadan has discovered the username of the user running the backdoor.[1]
Dumont, R., M.Léveillé, M., Porcher, H. (2018, December 1). THE DARK SIDE OF THE FORSSHE A landscape of OpenSSH backdoors. Retrieved July 16, 2020.

Kessel is an advanced version of OpenSSH which acts as a custom backdoor, mainly acting to steal credentials and function as a bot. Kessel has been active since its C2 domain began resolving in August 2018.[1]
Kessel can RC4-encrypt credentials before sending to the C2.[1]
Kessel can create a reverse shell between the infected host and a specified system.[1]
Kessel has maliciously altered the OpenSSH binary on targeted systems to create a backdoor.[1]
Kessel has exfiltrated data via hexadecimal-encoded subdomain fields of DNS queries.[1]
Kessel can split the data to be exilftrated into chunks that will fit in subdomains of DNS queries.[1]
Kessel has decrypted the binary's configuration once the main function was launched.[1]
Kessel can exfiltrate credentials and other information via HTTP POST request, TCP, and DNS.[1]
Kessel has exfiltrated information gathered from the infected system to the C2 server.[1]
Kessel can download additional modules from the C2 server.[1]
Kessel has trojanized the ssh_login and user-auth_pubkey functions to steal plaintext credentials.[1]
Kessel's configuration is hardcoded and RC4 encrypted within the binary.[1]
Kessel can use a proxy during exfiltration if set in the configuration.[1]
Kessel has collected the system architecture, OS version, and MAC address information.[1]
Kessel has collected the DNS address of the infected host.[1]
Dumont, R., M.Léveillé, M., Porcher, H. (2018, December 1). THE DARK SIDE OF THE FORSSHE A landscape of OpenSSH backdoors. Retrieved July 16, 2020.
